Escaping Saddle Points in Heterogeneous Federated Learning
via Distributed SGD with Communication Compression

Sijin Chen
Princeton Princeton University; email: chensj@princeton.edu. â€ƒâ€ƒ Zhize Li
CMU Carnegie Mellon University; emails: {zhizeli, yuejiechi}@cmu.edu. â€ƒâ€ƒ Yuejie Chi22footnotemark: 2
CMU
Abstract

We consider the problem of finding second-order stationary points of heterogeneous federated learning (FL). Previous works in FL mostly focus on first-order convergence guarantees, which do not rule out the scenario of unstable saddle points. Meanwhile, it is a key bottleneck of FL to achieve communication efficiency without compensating the learning accuracy, especially when local data are highly heterogeneous across different clients. Given this, we propose a novel algorithm Power-EF that only communicates compressed information via a novel error-feedback scheme. To our knowledge, Power-EF is the first distributed and compressed SGD algorithm that provably escapes saddle points in heterogeneous FL without any data homogeneity assumptions. In particular, Power-EF improves to second-order stationary points after visiting first-order (possibly saddle) points, using additional gradient queries and communication rounds only of almost the same order required by first-order convergence, and the convergence rate exhibits a linear speedup in terms of the number of workers. Our theory improves/recovers previous results, while extending to much more tolerant settings on the local data. Numerical experiments are provided to complement the theory.

Keywords: distributed SGD, heterogeneous federated learning, communication compression, second-order convergence

1 Introduction

The prevalence of large-scale data and enormous model size in modern machine learning problems give rise to an increasing interest in distributed machine learning, where a number of clients cooperate to handle the extremely heavy computation in the learning task without the need to move data around.

We consider a distributed server-client setting. Heterogeneous federated learning.

Assumptions on data homogeneity across the clients can be deployed to underplay this problem to a certain extent, since intuitively, there are less disagreements across the local objectives to reconcile. For example, each local dataset ğ’²(i)superscriptğ’²ğ‘–\mathcal{W}^{(i)} may take similar distributions, or may be uploaded to a data center that maintains global knowledge (KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al.,, 2016). However, in many real applications such as Internet of Things (IoT) (Savazzi etÂ al.,, 2020; Nguyen etÂ al.,, 2021), smart healthcare (Xu etÂ al.,, 2021), and networked model devices (Kang etÂ al.,, 2020), such assumptions become impractical in that local datasets display a strongly heterogeneous pattern, while they should not be exchanged or exposed to a third party due to privacy sensitivity or communication infeasibility (KoneÄnÃ½ etÂ al.,, 2016). These thorny scenarios of data heterogeneity correspond to a framework for distributed learning, namely federated learning (FL) (Kairouz etÂ al.,, 2019), which is now accumulating special attention from both academia and industry. The heterogeneous data constitute a major challenge in the distributed optimization problem under federated settings, which we refer to as heterogeneous FL.

Distributed SGD with communication compression.

A prevalent approach to solve (1) is by distributed stochastic gradient descent (SGD) (Koloskova etÂ al.,, 2020), a family of algorithms following the essential idea that each client computes its local stochastic gradient and then sends the gradient (or a carefully designed surrogate for the gradient) to the central server for parameter update. Distributed SGD has to take good care of communication efficiency: due to the large client number nğ‘›n (Savazzi etÂ al.,, 2020) and model scale dğ‘‘d (Brown etÂ al.,, 2020) in modern machine learning tasks, the communication cost from the clients to the server becomes the main bottleneck of optimization. Moreover, many resource constraints in real communication systems, such as limited bandwidth and stringent delay requirements, also highlight the importance of establishing efficient communication for the distributed training procedure.

A natural method to attain communication efficiency is (lossy) compression: one can deploy a compressor ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} in distributed SGD, which compresses any message ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} the client would like to send to the server, so that the traffic ğ’â€‹(ğ’™)ğ’ğ’™\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}) takes up a smaller bandwidth. In literature, a randomized operator ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be a Î¼ğœ‡\mu-compressor if the (expected) relative distortion of the compressed output is bounded by Î¼ğœ‡\mu (Stich etÂ al.,, 2018; RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin etÂ al.,, 2021; Huang etÂ al.,, 2022), which helps quantify the information loss due to compression.

Motivation.

It has been a recent interest to establish convergence results for distributed SGD with communication compression. Many among these works (Stich etÂ al.,, 2018; Koloskova etÂ al., 2019a, ; Xie etÂ al.,, 2020; Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Huang etÂ al.,, 2022) assume bounded local gradients â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤G2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™2superscriptğº2\left\|{\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq G^{2}, or bounded dissimilarity of local gradients 1nâ€‹â€–âˆ‘i=1nâˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ’™)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤G21ğ‘›superscriptnormsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™2superscriptğº2\frac{1}{n}\left\|{\sum_{i=1}^{n}\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq G^{2}, reflecting a reliance on data homogeneity that fails to hold in heterogeneous FL. Another body of the works (RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin etÂ al.,, 2021; RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al.,, 2022; Zhao etÂ al.,, 2022), although allowing heterogeneous data, only ensures first-order optimality, i.e. convergence to an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary point ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} with â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–â‰¤Ïµnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ’™italic-Ïµ\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|\leq\epsilon, which does not suffice to justify the goodness of the solution in the nonconvex setting where saddle points are abundant and do not necessarily lead to generalizable performance (Dauphin etÂ al.,, 2014). It is then important to obtain second-order convergence guarantees that ensure the algorithm escapes the saddle points and converges to an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-optimal second-order stationary point, with an additional control on the Hessian positive-definiteness that says âˆ’Î»minâ€‹(âˆ‡2fâ€‹(ğ’™))â‰¤Oâ€‹(Ïµ)subscriptğœ†superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“ğ’™ğ‘‚italic-Ïµ-\lambda_{\min}(\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}))\leq O\left(\sqrt{\epsilon}\right). Despite the growing literature of saddle-point escaping algorithms in the centralized setting (Jin etÂ al.,, 2021; Ge etÂ al.,, 2015; Li,, 2019; Daneshmand etÂ al.,, 2018), to the best of our knowledge, no existing distributed SGD algorithms succeed with second-order guarantees in the presence of both communication compression and data heterogeneity. In summary, the current research sparked a natural question as the primary concern of this paper:

On heterogeneous data, is there a distributed SGD algorithm with communication compression that attains second-order convergence guarantees for nonconvex problems?

1.1 Our contribution

To the best of our knowledge, this work is the first to answer the above question affirmatively. Our specific contributions are as follows.

  • â€¢

    A novel error-feedback mechanism: we propose Power-EF, a new distributed SGD algorithm that contains a novel error-feedback mechanism for communication compression.

  • â€¢

    First-order convergence: we prove that, with high probability, Power-EF converges to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary points within O~â€‹(1nâ€‹Ïµ4+1Î¼1.5â€‹Ïµ3)~ğ‘‚1ğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµ41superscriptğœ‡1.5superscriptitalic-Ïµ3\tilde{O}\left(\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}\right) stochastic gradient queries and communication rounds. The algorithm shows a linear speedup pattern in that the convergence rate benefits with the increase of the number of workers nğ‘›n.

  • â€¢

    Second-order convergence: we prove that, with high probability, Power-EF escapes the saddle points and converges to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-optimal second-order stationary points within O~â€‹(1nâ€‹Ïµ4+1Î¼1.5â€‹Ïµ3+Î¼â€‹n+1Î¼3â€‹Ïµ2.5)~ğ‘‚1ğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµ41superscriptğœ‡1.5superscriptitalic-Ïµ3ğœ‡ğ‘›1superscriptğœ‡3superscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5\tilde{O}\left(\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}+\frac{\mu n+1}{\mu^{3}\epsilon^{2.5}}\right) stochastic gradient queries and communication rounds. This suggests that Power-EF finds second-order stationary points with almost the same order of gradient and communication complexities as it takes to for first-order convergence.

  • â€¢

    Convergence under arbitrary data heterogeneity: importantly, the theory of Power-EF does not require assumptions on data similarity between different clients, thus allowing arbitrary heterogeneity in federated learning tasks.

1.2 Related works

Communication compression.

A communication operator, or a compressor, is deployed to reduce the communication cost in distributed SGD. Various instances of compressors include Quantized SGD (Alistarh etÂ al.,, 2017) that rounds real-valued gradient vectors to discrete buckets, Sign SGD (Bernstein etÂ al.,, 2018) that represents the gradient with the sign of each coordinate, Top-kğ‘˜k (Stich etÂ al.,, 2018) that selects kğ‘˜k coordinates out of the total dimension dğ‘‘d with the largest magnitudes, and Random-kğ‘˜k (Stich etÂ al.,, 2018) that performs the above selection uniformly at random, among others. Regardless of the specific design, a general biased compressor is characterized by a parameter Î¼âˆˆ(0,1]ğœ‡01\mu\in(0,1] that controls the aforementioned distortion of the operator.

With a compressor at hand, one also needs a mechanism that specifies what message should be compressed and transmitted between clients. A naive, prototypical mechanism is to directly replace the gradient with its compressed version and then conduct the update step as what is done in regular SGD, for example ğ’™t+1=ğ’™tâˆ’Î·â‹…ğ’â€‹(âˆ‡~â€‹fâ€‹(ğ’™t))subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡â‹…ğœ‚ğ’~âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\bm{x}_{t+1}=\bm{x}_{t}-\eta\cdot\mathcal{C}(\tilde{\nabla}f(\bm{x}_{t})) or its momentum variants. This mechanism underpins Alistarh etÂ al., (2017); Bernstein etÂ al., (2018), among others. However, error may accumulate in this simple replacement due to the lossy compression and menace its convergence. Various works propose new mechanisms to properly handle the error to boost the convergence performance, including Error-Feedback (Seide etÂ al.,, 2014; Stich etÂ al.,, 2018; Karimireddy etÂ al.,, 2019; Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Li etÂ al.,, 2022) and its variants (RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al.,, 2021; Fatkhullin etÂ al.,, 2021; Huang etÂ al.,, 2022), with adaptations to decentralized optimization (Koloskova etÂ al., 2019a, ; Koloskova etÂ al., 2019b, ; Zhao etÂ al.,, 2022). Most of the works guarantee first-order convergence subject to different levels of assumptions on data homogeneity, cf. Tables 1 and 2.

Second-order convergence of gradient methods.

It is well-known that gradient methods converge to first-order stationary points (Nesterov,, 2004). In non-convex problems, however, first-order convergence can be easily attacked by saddle points that may trap the GD trajectory. It is therefore important to investigate whether the algorithm is capable of escaping saddle points and converging to second-order stationary points. Asymptotically, Lee etÂ al., (2016) proved that GD with random initialization converges to a local minimum almost surely. However, the algorithm may still have to take an exponential time to escape the saddle points (Du etÂ al.,, 2017).

As to the polynomial-time guarantees, it is known that perturbing the gradient with isotropic noise helps GD converge to local minimizers (Ge etÂ al.,, 2015; Jin etÂ al.,, 2017). The perturbation technique gives rise to similar guarantees for other gradient methods, from SGD (Jin etÂ al.,, 2021) to SVRG (Ge etÂ al.,, 2019) and stochastic recursive gradient descent (Li,, 2019). On the other hand, instead of gradient perturbation, Daneshmand etÂ al., (2018) establishes the saddle-escaping property of SGD under an additional Correlated Negative Curvature (CNC) assumption regarding the statistical property of the stochastic gradient oracle.

Recently, Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021) leverages the perturbation technique to analyze the second-order stationarity of SGD with communication compression. The derivation is based on single-node implementation, which does not directly extend to the distributed settings. Further, it requires a conditional reset procedure in each iteration to achieve second-order convergence, at the expense of high communication cost as the server has to collect and maintain the local error terms using an uncompressed channel. Therefore, it remains obscure if the results therein still apply to the distributed setting with communication efficiency demands.

2 Problem Formulation

This paper is concerned with solving the nonconvex finite-sum minimization problem in a federated setting, while each client should only query a local stochastic gradient oracle, and communicate their information with the server in an efficient manner using compression. We detail this formulation in the following.

2.1 Nonconvex finite-sum minimization

Recall that we consider a federated optimization problem of finding an optimal parameter ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} to minimize the local objectives {fi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{f_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n} in an averaged manner, which is stated as an unconstrained finite-sum minimization problem:

minğ’™âˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(ğ’™):=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nfiâ€‹(ğ’™),assignsubscriptğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ’™1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ’™\displaystyle\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}f(\bm{x}):=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}f_{i}(\bm{x}),

where {fi}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘›\{f_{i}\}_{i=1}^{n}â€™s are the local objective functions, and nğ‘›n is the number of clients.

We focus on the case where the objective functions are nonconvex, subject to the following assumptions.

We emphasize that no assumption is made on the boundedness of, or similarity between, the local gradients.

Assumption 2.5 is a high-probability variant of the commonly-used bounded variance assumption, stated in expectation. 2.3 Communication compression

To enable efficient communication over bandwidth-limited scenarios, our setting requests that the communication between the clients and the server should be compressed according to a possibly randomized scheme ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. Specifically, for any input ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the scheme outputs a surrogate ğ’â€‹(ğ’™)âˆˆâ„dğ’ğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})\in\mathbb{R}^{d} so that the transmission of ğ’â€‹(ğ’™)ğ’ğ’™\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}) between machines would take up a smaller bandwidth than the direct transmission of ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x}.

Definition 2.6.

A possibly random mapping ğ’:â„dâ†’â„d:ğ’â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathcal{C}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be a Î¼ğœ‡\mu-compressor for some Î¼âˆˆ(0,1]ğœ‡01\mu\in(0,1] if

â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’â€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼)â€‹â€–ğ’™â€–2,âˆ€ğ’™âˆˆâ„d.formulae-sequencesuperscriptnormğ’™ğ’ğ’™21ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’™2for-allğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2},\quad\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Definition 2.6 slightly deviates from the conventional definition that controls the expected distortion, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ’™âˆ’ğ’â€‹(ğ’™)â€–2]â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼)â€‹â€–ğ’™â€–2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormğ’™ğ’ğ’™21ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’™2\mathbb{E}[\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}]\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2}, to facilitate the derivation of high-probability results. Examples of compressors that satisfy Definition 2.6 include Top-kğ‘˜k (Stich etÂ al.,, 2018) and a family of compressors named general biased rounding (Beznosikov etÂ al.,, 2020).

3 Proposed Algorithm

This section introduces our proposed algorithm Power-EF that is suitable to heterogeneous FL with communication compression.

3.1 Fast Compressed Communication

We first introduce the Fast Compressed Communication (FCC) module proposed by Huang etÂ al., (2022), which is deployed at each client in their compressed SGD algorithm NEOLITHIC. For input ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the FCC module with parameter pâˆˆâ„¤+ğ‘subscriptâ„¤p\in\mathbb{Z}_{+} recursively computes the residual {ğ’—i}i=1psuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘\{\bm{v}_{i}\}_{i=1}^{p} for pğ‘p rounds, where

ğ’—1=ğ’™;ğ’—i=ğ’™âˆ’âˆ‘j=1iâˆ’1ğ’â€‹(ğ’—j),i=2,â€¦,p.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’—1ğ’™formulae-sequencesubscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘–1ğ’subscriptğ’—ğ‘—ğ‘–2â€¦ğ‘\bm{v}_{1}=\bm{x};\quad\bm{v}_{i}=\bm{x}-\sum_{j=1}^{i-1}\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{j}),\quad i=2,...,p.

It then outputs FCCpâ€‹(ğ’™)=âˆ‘i=1pğ’â€‹(ğ’—i)subscriptFCCğ‘ğ’™superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ğ’subscriptğ’—ğ‘–\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})=\sum_{i=1}^{p}\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{i}). To transmit the output to the server efficiently, the client transmits the set of compressed vectors {ğ’â€‹(ğ’—i)}i=1psuperscriptsubscriptğ’subscriptğ’—ğ‘–ğ‘–1ğ‘\{\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}_{i})\}_{i=1}^{p} through the channel, and the exact output is assembled by summation on the server side.

Defining ğ’Ÿ:ğ’™â†¦ğ’™âˆ’ğ’â€‹(ğ’™):ğ’Ÿmaps-toğ’™ğ’™ğ’ğ’™\mathcal{D}:\bm{x}\mapsto\bm{x}-\mathcal{C}(\bm{x}), one can observe that FCCpâ€‹(ğ’™)=ğ’™âˆ’ğ’Ÿpâ€‹(ğ’™)subscriptFCCğ‘ğ’™ğ’™superscriptğ’Ÿğ‘ğ’™\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})=\bm{x}-\mathcal{D}^{p}(\bm{x}). In fact, the FCC module is able to refine the compression loss by harnessing the contraction property of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. Specifically, ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} is a contraction because â€–ğ’Ÿâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼)â€‹â€–ğ’™â€–2superscriptnormğ’Ÿğ’™21ğœ‡superscriptnormğ’™2\left\|{\mathcal{D}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2} due to Definition 2.6. Hence, the error of the FCC module â€–ğ’™âˆ’FCCpâ€‹(ğ’™)â€–2â‰¤(1âˆ’Î¼)pâ€‹â€–ğ’™â€–2superscriptnormğ’™subscriptFCCğ‘ğ’™2superscript1ğœ‡ğ‘superscriptnormğ’™2\left\|{\bm{x}-\mathrm{FCC}_{p}(\bm{x})}\right\|^{2}\leq(1-\mu)^{p}\left\|{\bm{x}}\right\|^{2} enjoys a geometric decay with pğ‘p.

3.2 Power-EF

We integrate the FCC module into our algorithm Power-EF, as summarized in Algorithm 1. The algorithm takes as input an initial model ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0}, step size Î·ğœ‚\eta, FCC parameter pğ‘p, perturbation radius rğ‘Ÿr, and the number of iterations Tğ‘‡T. After a simple initialization procedure, Power-EF iteratively produces a sequence {ğ’™t}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0ğ‘‡\{\bm{x}_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T} to gradually update the initial model by SGD-type descent. In each iteration, we use the accumulated gradient âˆ‡~pâ€‹fisubscript~âˆ‡ğ‘subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\tilde{\nabla}_{p}f_{i} to balance the number of communication rounds and stochastic gradient complexity. Each iteration of Power-EF contains four conceptual stages interpreted as follows.

  • â€¢

    Feedback the local gradient estimate. We intend to use ğ’†t(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’†ğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{e}_{t}^{(i)}, the error up to the last iteration, to feedback our estimate of the local gradient ğ’ˆt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} for the current round. Firstly, based on the error, the client invokes FCC module to compute the feedback term ğ’˜t(i)+ğ’„t(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’˜ğ‘¡ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ’„ğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{w}_{t}^{(i)}+\bm{c}_{t}^{(i)} (Line 9â€“10). Then each client iğ‘–i gets its current gradient estimate ğ’ˆt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} by complementing the existing estimate ğ’ˆtâˆ’1(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡1ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t-1}^{(i)} with the feedback term (Line 11).

  • â€¢

    Update the error. Upon completion of the feedback, we increase the error term by the discrepancy between the real stochastic gradient (after artificial perturbation) and our local estimate ğ’ˆt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)} (Line 12). In this way, the error term essentially stores the cumulative estimation discrepancy of ğ’ˆt(i)superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)}, which is ready for feedback again on the next run.

  • â€¢

    Prepare the global gradient estimate. The update of global gradient estimate is conducted on a par with the local update method in an averaged manner (Line 16), so that we always have ğ’ˆt=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nğ’ˆt(i)subscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘›superscriptsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡ğ‘–\bm{g}_{t}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}\bm{g}_{t}^{(i)}.

  • â€¢

    Update the model. Finally, the server updates the current model ğ’™tsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\bm{x}_{t} by a descending step along our global gradient estimate ğ’ˆtsubscriptğ’ˆğ‘¡\bm{g}_{t} (LineÂ 17).

3.3 Discussion

At its core, Power-EF benefits from the power contraction underlying the FCC module to upgrade the classical error-feedback mechanism (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021; Stich etÂ al.,, 2018), hence the name. Specifically, our algorithm inherits the classical design of error term to track the cumulative discrepancy of gradient estimation (Line 12), but refines the way errors are used to feedback the current gradient estimation by the FCC module. Moreover, while still guaranteeing second-order results, Power-EF manages to remove from the prior work (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021) an expensive procedure of conditinal reset that inevitably occupies the uncompressed bandwidth.

Data heterogeneity.

Mathematically, our mechanism is able to induce an error term recurrence irrelavent to local gradients, thus circumventing from data similarity assumptions. This favorable property originates from our design of Power-EF, which is nontrivially different from the existing NEOLITHIC (Huang etÂ al.,, 2022) algorithm where FCC module also plays a part. For example, NEOLITHIC inputs the gradient estimate to FCC while we input the estimation discrepancy, and error terms are also computed distinctly. As a notable result, contrary to our algorithm, the theory of NEOLITHIC still has to assume local gradient similarity.

Gradient perturbation.

We add an isotropic Gaussian noise to each stochastic gradient to help the model escape from saddle points. Intuitively, around saddle points, the isotropic perturbation ensures that the SGD trajectory can traverse a sufficient distance along the descending direction, i.e. the eigenvector of Hessian âˆ‡2fâ€‹(ğ’™t)superscriptâˆ‡2ğ‘“subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\nabla^{2}f(\bm{x}_{t}) with a negative eigenvalue, thus escaping the saddle region and gaining an objective decrease. The perturbation is not required for first-order convergence, in which case one can safely set r=0ğ‘Ÿ0r=0.

4 Performance Guarantees

In this section, we state the theoretical guarantees for Power-EF, where the proofs are deferred to the appendix. To begin, we first define the first-order and second-order approximate stationarity conditions.

Definition 4.1.

ğ’™âˆˆâ„dğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is said to be an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-optimal first-order stationary point (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-FOSP) if â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–â‰¤Ïµnormâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ±italic-Ïµ\left\|{\nabla f(\bm{x})}\right\|\leq\epsilon.

Definition 4.2.

Otherwise, ğ±ğ±\bm{x} is said to be an Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-strict saddle point.

Second-order convergence guarantee.

Unlike TheoremÂ 4.3, perturbing the local stochastic gradient with an appropriate radius plays a vital part in the second-order guarantee by assisting the iterates to escape the saddle points. Again, we can compute the gradient complexity and communication rounds of Power-EF to attain second-order optimality, given as follows.

Corollary 4.6 (Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-SOSP complexity).

Under the same setting of Theorem 4.5, Algorithm 1 requires O~â€‹(1nâ€‹Ïµ4+1Î¼1.5â€‹Ïµ3+Î¼â€‹n+1Î¼3â€‹Ïµ2.5)~ğ‘‚1ğ‘›superscriptitalic-Ïµ41superscriptğœ‡1.5superscriptitalic-Ïµ3ğœ‡ğ‘›1superscriptğœ‡3superscriptitalic-Ïµ2.5\tilde{O}\Big{(}\frac{1}{n\epsilon^{4}}+\frac{1}{\mu^{1.5}\epsilon^{3}}+\frac{\mu n+1}{\mu^{3}\epsilon^{2.5}}\Big{)} queries to the stochastic gradient oracle and communication rounds.

According to the corollaries, Power-EF improves to second-order stationary points after visiting first-order (possibly saddle) points, using additional gradient queries and communication rounds only of almost the same order required by first-order convergence when Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon is typically small to be the dominant parameter. Contrary to another work allowing heterogeneous data (Fatkhullin etÂ al.,, 2021), our convergence rate exhibits a linear speedup in terms of nğ‘›n, implying that our algorithm significantly benefits from the distributed framework.

5 Numerical Experiments

In this section, we present the performance of Power-EF in distributed learning experiments to validate its efficiency empirically. We train a ResNet18 model on CIFAR10 dataset (Krizhevsky and Hinton,, 2009) using 4 clients and 1 server and compare the performance of various distributed optimization algorithms in the training task, including standard distributed SGD, SGD with naive compression, standard EF, and Power-EF. All the training procedures take 100 epochs with a step size of 10âˆ’2superscript10210^{-2} and weight decay of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}. For communication compression, we use Top-kğ‘˜k compressor that keeps top 1% coordinates of the largest magnitudes, and Power-EF is tested with exponent p=1,4,8ğ‘148p=1,4,8 respectively. The algorithms are implemented on PyTorch (Paszke etÂ al.,, 2019) 2.0.0 and the experiments are conducted on NVIDIA Tesla P100 GPU.

We summarize the results in Figure 1. According to Figure 1(a) and 1(b), without the feedback mechanism, the lossy compression significantly hinders the the convergence speed and prediction accuracy. On the other hand, EF and Power-EF have a comparable performance in boosting the training procedure and improving the accuracy. According to Figure 1(a), increasing the FCC parameter pğ‘p, the convergence speed is almost not affected while an improved test loss is obtained in the final stage. A comparison between the communication efficiency of different algorithms is drawn in Figure 1(c). The compressor remarkably scales down the communication cost of the training procedure, from nearly 104superscript10410^{4} GB to no more than 102superscript10210^{2} GB for 100 epochs.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we propose and analyze Power-EF, which is the first distributed SGD algorithm with communication compression that provably attains second-order optimality under heterogeneous data, to the best of our knowledge. Specifically, subject to mild and standard assumptions, we show that Power-EF converges to Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-SOSPs with high probability, which is almost on par with the gradient and communication complexity it takes to find Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-FOSPs, and the convergence rate shows a linear speedup with respect to nğ‘›n. Our theory are complemented by the performance of Power-EF in the distributed learning experiments. For future work, it will be of great interest to develop privacy-preserving distributed SGD algorithms that can escape saddle points with communication compression.

Appendix B Proof of First-order Convergence

In this section we detail the proof of Theorem 4.3, a first-order convergence guarantee for Power-EF. To this end, we first provide a bound for the compression error â€–ğ’†tâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’†ğ‘¡2\left\|{\bm{e}_{t}}\right\|^{2} (Lemma B.2), which supports an argument (Lemma B.3) that controls the true gradient norm of the iterates produced by Power-EF. Finally, an appropriate choice of parameters leads Lemma B.3 to the desired Theorem 4.3.

B.1 Compression error bound

We will use the following two lemmas to bound â€–ğ’†tâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’†ğ‘¡2\left\|{\bm{e}_{t}}\right\|^{2}. The first lemma controls â€–ğ’™t+1âˆ’ğ’™tâ€–2superscriptnormsubscriptğ’™ğ‘¡1subscriptğ’™ğ‘¡2\left\|{\bm{x}_{t+1}-\bm{x}_{t}}\right\|^{2}, that is the difference between two consecutive iterates; the second technical lemma upper bounds a useful linear recurrence relation.

Lemma B.1.

Suppose that Assumption 2.2 holds, and Î·â‰¤12â€‹Lğœ‚12ğ¿\eta\leq\frac{1}{2L}. Then, the iterates {ğ±t}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0ğ‘‡\{\bm{x}_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T} generated by Algorithm 1 satisfy

Appendix C Proof of Second-order Convergence

The core idea for establishing the second-order convergence result (Theorem 4.5) is to show that, when Power-EF encounters a saddle point, the objective can still descend sufficiently after finitely many additional iterations (Lemma C.10).

Two arguments are developed to support this favorable property of Power-EF dynamics. Firstly, we show an improve-or-localize behavior of Power-EF (Lemma C.3): if the iterates {ğ’št}subscriptğ’šğ‘¡\{\bm{y}_{t}\} escape (move far enough) from a saddle point, the objective must descend sufficiently.

Secondly, we claim that the iterates do escape from saddle points (Corollary C.9). This nontrivial claim is obtained using the coupling sequences technique. To be specific, we craft another sequence {ğ’štâ€²}subscriptsuperscriptğ’šâ€²ğ‘¡\{\bm{y}^{\prime}_{t}\} mirroring the original iterates {ğ’št}subscriptğ’šğ‘¡\{\bm{y}_{t}\} along the escape direction of a saddle point. We show that the gap between the coupling sequences â€–ğ’štâˆ’ğ’štâ€²â€–normsubscriptğ’šğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptğ’šâ€²ğ‘¡\left\|{\bm{y}_{t}-\bm{y}^{\prime}_{t}}\right\| expands sufficiently after finitely many iterations (Lemma C.8), which implies {ğ’št}subscriptğ’šğ‘¡\{\bm{y}_{t}\} travels far from the saddle point.

This workflow of establishing second-order convergence guarantees stems from pioneering works on plain GD and SGD (Jin etÂ al.,, 2017, 2021), and finds similar applications in several recent works such as recursive SGD (Li,, 2019), and compressed SGD (Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev,, 2021). While the theory in Avdiukhin and Yaroslavtsev, (2021) entails respective discussions on the large-gradient case and small-gradient case, Power-EF avoids such intricacies due to the technical fact that our bound for ğ’†tsubscriptğ’†ğ‘¡\bm{e}_{t} does not involve gradient norm terms.

For conciseness, we presume the following parameter setting for our theory and do not restate them therein.

C.1 Uniform error bound

From Lemma C.8, we observe that the difference between the coupling sequences has an exponential growth with time tğ‘¡t, under the assumption that the iterates get stuck around the saddle points. Intuitively, after a sufficiently long period, it is contradictory to grow exponentailly and remain stuck at the same time. We now validate this intuition and show that the iterates generated by Power-EF is able to escape the saddle points.

C.4 Convergence

Combining Corollary C.9 with the improve-or-localize behavior of Power-EF (Lemma C.3), we conclude that the objective receives sufficient descent.

Proof of Theorem 4.5.

All the iterates can be classified into three types, namely (i) iterates that are not Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-FOSPs, (ii) Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-strict saddle points, and (iii) Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-SOSPs. By Theorem 4.3, we have showed that at most 1/4 of the iterates are not Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-FOSPs. Therefore, it suffices to show that at most 1/4 of the iterates are Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-strict saddle points.
